stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily focused on designing and blocking out the layout for a red coin sub-area inside the pyramid of Course 14. He worked through the core design challenge of creating a maze that feels confusing at first but resolves intuitively. He also showcased a completed, difficult saw-blade section from Course 15 and discussed playtesting feedback from Zeina.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing a pyramid sub-area for Course 14 to be a maze that resolves itself through player intuition rather than explicit puzzle-solving. The final design involves a main path with multiple branching shortcuts containing red coins.
development_findings.quote: I want this to be more like confusion and then the confusion resolves, because you understand it. Which does sound a lot like a puzzle. The difference is that there's no active effort required from the player. Rather, you just do the thing, and without really thinking about it, you suddenly understand it.

development_findings.summary: A difficult saw-blade section in Course 15 features a dynamic difficulty mechanic where the speed of the saws is tied to the player's movement speed, a form of 'rubber-banding'.
development_findings.quote: The timer starts going as soon as you enter a certain range from them and then they go. But the slower you move the slower the saws are so there's a bit of rubber banding here basically.

development_findings.summary: Kaze considered and rejected a 'footprints' feature to show players where they've been in the pyramid maze due to the high technical effort and potential for performance issues on the N64.
development_findings.quote: It's possible to program, but like... Ugh... You know what I mean? Ugh... That would probably also lead to a crit at some point.

development_findings.summary: A new bug was discovered that allows for a Backwards Long Jump (BLJ), which Kaze immediately identified as a very important bug to fix.
The project's scope has increased, pushing the release past the original end-of-2024 target due to a team decision to add more polish.
development_findings.quote: The original demo only took like 3 or 4 months. And it had 4 finished levels. I really wanted to repolish the hack. Like 2024? End of 2024? That's like the original timeline. And I mean I had some time to hit that target, but then we decided to polish it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to implement a system where the level's music, provided by Sauraen, dynamically changes based on the player's location within a level, transitioning between themes for different biomes.

Based on player feedback for his other hack 'Missing Link', Kaze made specific changes: altering a room's geometry to provide a better puzzle hint and removing thorns from a boss arena to make the fight easier for less skilled players.
A demo featuring only Course 1 is ready to be compiled and released.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's game design philosophy is heavily influenced by Majora's Mask, preferring its focus on world-building and integrated side quests over the linear dungeon-to-dungeon progression of games like Ocarina of Time and Twilight Princess.
context_findings.quote: What I really like about Zelda is all the in-between. And then I was thinking back to Ocarina of Time and Ocarina of Time doesn't have much of the in-between either. It's also just like dungeon dungeon dungeon. But Majora's Mask. I think Majora's Mask formula is perfect.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in designing levels that force players to understand a system rather than use simple exploits, like the 'follow the left wall' strategy in mazes.
context_findings.quote: I want to force the player to engage in your freedom. And forced to understand what the puzzle looks like or the pyramid looks like. And you can't just follow the left wall.

context_findings.summary: Kaze briefly explores the philosophical conflict of wealth inequality, acknowledging the logical imperative to give to the poor but admitting his own lack of motivation to act on it.
context_findings.quote: If you want to live morally, how can you live without giving almost all your money to people that are poorer? ... How can you justify not doing that? Something I don't understand. Unfortunately, I don't care about it that much.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is transparent about his finances from modding, revealing he makes about $10,000 a year from YouTube, and his family's monthly expenses are around $2,800 USD.
context_findings.quote: I am pretty transparent about how much I make from ROM hacking, right? You can just... I definitely shot my YouTube analytics before. Look, my analytics. $900 this month. Or in a year, it's like... $10,000. It's not that much.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes wages in the professional game industry are lower because it's a passion-driven field that people actively want to work in.
context_findings.quote: I think in the video game industry, the wages are like something like 30% lower than outside video games. ... The incentive to work in the video game industry is that you like doing it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of potential community backlash and controversy, citing a past incident where the name of a Mario enemy, 'Nipper', was mistaken for a racial slur.
context_findings.quote: I already almost get cancelled over the nippers in course 3. It's been more like, nipper? That's a racial slur, that's not a mario enemy. I'm thinking, yep, that is a mario enemy. Please do not murder me.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a specific creative suggestion to improve the 'Styrofoam' texture, proposing an alternative of cardboard with stapled paper to better fit the craft aesthetic.
biobak.quote: Biobak was saying maybe cardboard where paper is stapled onto it. And yeah, that could probably look better.

zeina.summary: Zeina serves as a key playtester for the game. Her difficulty in beating a new saw-blade section in Course 15 served as direct feedback for Kaze, making him worry about the level's balance.
zeina.quote: I mean I had Zeina trying to play it and she didn't really have a shot at beating it so that's why I feel like it's a little difficult.

zeina.summary: Kaze shares a personal anecdote about a disagreement with Zeina over the existence of a person named 'Tommy Tomato', offering a small glimpse into their personal dynamic outside of development.

key_stories.title: Designing the Resolving Pyramid Maze
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to design a maze-like level that wasn't frustrating. After considering and rejecting several complex ideas, he devised a concept of a single main path with many branching shortcuts, allowing the player to learn the layout through exploration and eventually master it.
key_stories.challenge: To design a red coin sub-area inside a pyramid that felt like a confusing maze but would become intuitively navigable once the player understood its core concept, avoiding typical maze frustrations.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed several ideas, including landmarks, color-coded paths, and a central hub. He rejected ideas like player-generated footprints due to technical difficulty and a clock-like layout due to backtracking. He arrived at the 'main path with shortcuts' idea as the best way to create a sense of initial confusion that resolves into understanding.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze settled on a design featuring one long, main path with numerous smaller shortcut paths branching off and reconnecting to it. The red coins are on these shortcuts, encouraging exploration and rewarding players who learn the layout, allowing them to navigate it efficiently.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to be more like confusion and then the confusion resolves, because you understand it. ... The difference is that there's no active effort required from the player. Rather, you just do the thing, and without really thinking about it, you suddenly understand it.

key_stories.title: Calibrating Difficulty via Playtesting
key_stories.summary: Kaze worried a new level section was too hard. He had his wife, Zeina, playtest it, and her struggles confirmed his fears, demonstrating their collaborative process for balancing difficulty.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze designed a saw-blade platforming section for Course 15 that he suspected was too difficult for the average player.
key_stories.process: To test his difficulty concerns, Kaze had his wife, Zeina, play the level. She struggled significantly, confirming his fears. He had already implemented a 'rubber-banding' mechanic where the saws slow down if the player moves slowly, but her feedback showed it might not be enough.
key_stories.outcome: The section remains in the game, but Kaze is still concerned about its high difficulty. The incident highlights the team's reliance on internal playtesting to gauge difficulty and the ongoing challenge of balancing for a wide range of player skills.
key_stories.key_quote: I mean I had Zeina trying to play it and she didn't really have a shot at beating it so that's why I feel like it's a little difficult.

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to implement a global coin counter that persists between levels, but does not want a '100 coin star' objective in each course. He brainstormed ways to teach this mechanic to the player, such as starting them with coins or having a 4-digit UI, but did not finalize the approach.

open_questions.context: Biobak was mentioned giving a texture suggestion and Zeina was mentioned as a playtester. The actual back-and-forth creative process and how feedback is integrated remains unclear. Badub, the composer, was not mentioned at all.
